Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 01:52PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Who are you, nsykes?  The problem with LE is not that the advice about flying and needles is wrong its that there is so little knowledge about LE out there.  Its the line at the bottom about women questioning all the other precautions that has us concerned.  First of all, it is irresponisble to refer so generally to all women.  It may be that women who had had bc surgery but no LE can fly without compression garments, but as a woman who does have LE I am in a very different position and would have a really terrible problem if I ever tried to fly without the garments.  Second, referring so generally to precautionary measures that we know can help prevent and control LE, without ANY evidence to back it up is beyond irresponsible.  The "rules about flying" that she refers to are the precaution of wearing compression garments.  Throwing off that rule would not only be dangerous, but it is not even close to what the women in the study did -- they WORE compression garments and exercised gradually.  And the rules about blood pressure and needles?  Do you really think a carefully controlled study in which women were protected throughout has any relationship to throwing off such time-worn precautions?  What Love seems to be saying there is that LE doesn't exist.  Or doesn't matter.  Why else would she be saying we should question ALL precautionary measures.  This is deeply insensitive to those of us who have to live with this disorder.
Posts.Title: Susan Love proclaims no need for lymphedema risk reductions kira TammyLou

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 06:39AM Member_of_the_Club wrote: I sent Love an e-mail and got the following response:   Thank you for responding to my blog about lymphedema.  The study I quoted was very carefully done and I think deserved to be discussed widely.   It was a good example of how assumptions had been made by the medical profession regarding how to prevent breast cancer that on testing have not been true. In general the precautions regarding prevention of lymphedema have not been evidence based.  My search of the literature showed only obesity (high BMI) being a reproducible risk factor followed by age and in some studies infection and injury.  I could not find any data demonstrating that having your blood pressure taken, having an IV placed or having blood drawn from an arm that has undergone axillary surgery will cause lymphedema.  Most of these precautions were suggested by surgeons and not tested. There have been only two studies regarding flying.  One was a questionnaire asking people what triggered their lymphedema.  There were only 173 women who were postmastectomy who answered the questionnaire.  Of these some (at most 22)  felt that flying had triggered their lymphedema.  The other was specifically on 287 women post mastectomy and compared flyers to non flyers and found no difference in the rates of lymphedema.  This data is not enough to make any recommendations regarding compression garments to prevent lymphedema.  (Obviously women with lymphedema may need to use them). Other precautions commonly recommended also should be studied rather than just accepted as true without evidence.  All this being said, I am sorry if my comment appeared flip.  I do think that lymphedema is a serious problem and that we need more research regarding treatment, and prevention.  I have been impressed by some recent papers about looking at lymph drainage from the arm prior to surgery, in order to better plan surgery.  My many years of breast surgery have suggested to me that some women have more lymphatic channels than others congenitally.  If you do a big resection on someone with few channels they will get lymphedema while someone with extensive channels will not.  This hypothesis is now being tested.  I am currently in process of writing the fifth edition of the Breast Book and welcome any input you would like to suggest for the section on lymphedema.  In addition my Foundation is collaborating with the City of Hope and the NCI to launch a study within the Love/Avon Army of Women.  We hope to collect data on a large number of women and follow them over twenty years.  This includes women with breast cancer and will be a perfect opportunity to question women about what precautions they take, what surgery they had etc and see if we can see some patterns regarding lymphedema.  I would love to find the answers to both prevention and treatment.   Again thank you for responding to the blog, and I am very sorry if I did not express myself well.  Sincerely, Susan Love  So if she's going to expand her discussion of LE, shouldn't we help her do it right?

Posts.Title: Advice for metsters konakat RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2011 02:09PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: You can get lymphedema with only one node removed but I would not restrict use of that arm.  When you fail to use the arm and it weakens you can be at higher risk for LE because of those times when you have to use the arm, you will be less prepared.  It sounds like the kind of carrying you are referring to is not new, and therefore should not cause new strain.  The most important thing to do is listen to your body.  If it feels different, sore or aching, stop with the lifting.  If you were considering sustained lifting, like with weight training, I would suggest seeing a lymphedema therapist to discuss if you should wear a sleeve for such occasions, but for things like carrying groceries and suitcases I think you should just keep doing what you've been doing.  Just listen to your body.

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 08:30PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: I'm a little concerned about this idea that "they don't know what works." This just runs counter to all the science on breast cancer. They know what works for MOST women. Unfortunately, they do not know what works for every woman. But that doesn't mean they are clueless about the treatments. Breast cancer survival rates have increased dramatically, treatments have become more targeted for the different sub-types of cancer. This is not a wide net. I know lots of women who have gone through breast cancer treatment and most of us have had different protocols and different drugs. There is a theme that runs through these boards -- hit the beast at first with everything you've got so hopefully you never see it again. Its just harder to treat the cancer if it comes back. Perhaps you should go to the moving on section and ask about the long term effects of rads. Most of us would says we have none. Some women report aches and pains down the road. I have not heard of a single one on these boards who died from rads. But plenty of women die from being undertreated. Sorry, I feel strongly about this.
Posts.Title: Informal Poll re:recurrences SISKimberly SISKimberly

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2008 01:42PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: I think you should be very careful about the conclusions you are drawing here. First of all, if it is a 20 year old study it should be taken with a grain of salt. Radiation in the old days (not that long ago, actually) was less focused, used higher amounts of radiation and was, in general, more dangerous than what they do today. Like everything else, they've gotten better and safer with the treatment. I would guess that the vast majority of women here with mets did everything, everything they possibly could. You can't draw from that fact that radiation doesn't work. For some women, it doesn't work. For most, it does. We can only go with the current state of knowledge and that is that the benefits of radiation outweigh the risks. I know a woman who had multiple positive nodes. She did chemo but chose to forego radiation, against her doctor's recommendation. She now has mets. I'm not saying that this would necessarily happen to you, but it is a cautionary tale.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2009 06:39AM Member_of_the_Club wrote: I'm another hand glove person and I also want to add that if its making things worse, its not fitting correctly and you need a new approach.  When you say "little" glove that makes me wonder if you have finger stubs.  You need a glove that will go all the way to your nail beds.  The compression level on your arm may also be a problem.  Since my swelling is fingers and rarely hand but not arm, my glove has heavy pressure but my armsleeve is actually a lighter compression level.    Finally there is the fit itself and it sounds like your glove is too tight on the wrist and too loose on the hand.  It may be that its the wrong size and it may be that you require a custom glove.  I agree with the others that it isn't just the garments and you need the other stuff as well.  But you really really need to go to someone who knows how to size and fit the garments.  Good luck.  Please check back and let us know how you are doing.  Once you get the proper fit it does get easier.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2008 10:28PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: I think sometimes women who are early stage (and I am not necessarily including Christina Applegate in this, just making a general observation) see themselves as the heros of their own story.  Of course we are all the heros of our own stories, but they tell their stories as if it is a sign of how they overcame cancer through grit, strength, determination. . . but what they leave out is luck.  This is a battle between the cancer cells and the drugs and we all hope the drugs win but we aren't yet at the point where the drugs are always stronger than the cancer.  Until then, those of us who are more fortunate need to be humble about our luck and recognize that it may be temporary, and in any event, we didn't bring it on ourselves.  I guess I'm feeling a bit testy because I recently saw a new breast cancer biography in the bookstore in which a woman writes about how awful her experience was and how she overcame it.  Turns out she had DCIS and wrote a whole book about her lumpectomy and how she was "butchered."  Now I am sure that it was an awful experience for her and I'm sure she feels she was butchered, but the whole thing somehow made me angry -- like doesn't she know what she was spared?  Doesn't she appreciate how lucky she was? I feel like a very small person for even having these thoughts, so please forgive me.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 10:00AM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Kelly, if its so overwhelming for you -- understandably -- why not call in some help?  Most cancer centers have oncology social workers on staff who can help you through this.  As with anything else in life, preparing yourself might help.  Think through the various ways in which they might react so you will be prepared, and hopefully less anxious abut the conversation.  And plan something for yourself afterwards, something to release the tension.  I haven't had to have this conversation but I did have to tell my son that he has Aspergers Syndrome, an autistic spectrum disorder.  It was very difficult for me to bring myself to have that conversation, I stressed a lot beforehand.  Turns out he had a similar reaction as Janis' kids when she told them her cancer was back.  He kind of did an okey-dokey whatever thing, but since that day the questions have come slowly.   he really has been thinking about this and taking control of the information.  Prepare yourself for that. It will most likely be more than one conversation and if your beautiful children feel comfortable enough to bring their questions up with you, they will adjust to the information.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2009 09:43AM Member_of_the_Club wrote: From one MOTC to another: I hope you are seeing a PT who is trained in treating LE.  A lot of this is individualized to your situation but I assume you've been fitted for compression garments.  You need to wear those when you fly, work out, and any time your affected arm feels uncomfortable (for me that includes long drives).  If your LE is more advanced you may have to wear them all day and wrap at night.  You should be very careful about cuts on that arm and apply an antibiotic cream when you get them.  Its also a good idea to use sunscreen to prevent sunburn on the arm.  Yeah, this sucks.  I was pretty depressed by it in the beginning as well.  But once I got used to managing it, I felt much better.  You will too.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 08:02AM Member_of_the_Club wrote: What I have read over and over again is that they believe at 1 centimeter, cancer cells escape into the bloodstream.  This is an estimation, of course.  There are women with smaller tumors who eventually develop mets and most likely women with larger tumors whose cancer is contained.  This is not misinformation.  Lymph nodes act as a kind of surrogate because there is no test for spread through the bloodstream.  if the nodes are positive, that is a strong indication that the cancer cells are out there.  If the nodes are negative, less so, but no guarantees.  Keep in mind also that the leveI of cancer cells in the bloodstream have to reach a certain, very high level before there are mets.  I certainly didn't mean to scare you.  You are getting the best care you can from an oncologist who is responding to the particulars of your case.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 07:25PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: I am also surprised they even did the oncotype test.  You are stage II with a highly aggressive tumor.  The her2neu overexpression is basically a tumor that is programmed to grow and spread.  Thank goodness for herceptin which is a miracle drug for many women.  You have kids and they need you.  Do the chemo.  Tamoxifen is not hormones, it is a drug that deceives the cancer cells into thinking they are getting estrogen, the fuel they need, when they are not.  I have been on tamoxifen for four years and I feel fine.  I ran six miles this morning.   Do everything you possibly can to live.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 06:24AM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Karen, you need to take a deep breath.  You have a three centimeter tumor.  Thats how big mine was, so i know it is big.  No oncologist, as far as I know, would consider an oncotype test for you because you are not in the grey area for chemo.  You need chemo.  Even if your lymph nodes are negative there is a very high chance that cancer cells got out through your bloodstream.  They say this most likely happens to any tumor over 1 centimeter, your's is well over that size.  Your anger at your oncologist seems completely unwarranted to me.  She is trying to save your life.  At the end she offered up the oncotype test anyway because she is hoping it will convince you to take lifesaving treatment.  Your reaction to that offer was to get even angrier.    You are getting angry at the messenger instead of the disease.  No one is trying to hurt you here.  You need chemo, you just do, so you can stick around to raise your children.

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 12:54PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: One thing to ask about if they ask at the hospital about a DNR is what would be left if your heart stopped and they did resuscitate you.  I went through this with my mother who had brain cancer.  I resisted the DNR for her because I wanted to give chemo and radiation a chance to work.  She didn't have the capacity at that point to make the call, although we were hoping she would regain functioning from the treatment.  A doctor finally said to me that if her heart stopped and they did resuscitate her, that the loss of blood to the brain from her heart having been temporarily stopped would leave her with no quality of life.  So I said OK to the DNR.    This was the first time I had heard that, that if the heart stops even if they revive a person, they will have brain damage.  I am now wondering if it is true.  I felt like the doctors were pushing the DNR awfully hard.  If I had it to do over again I would ask about this, what is the effect of having the heart stopped.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 12:35PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: My story:  a few months after I finished active treatment I started having daily sinus-type headaches.  They tended to be in the front of my head.  I went to my oncologist, who got angry with me for wasting his time.  That was the last time I saw that oncologist, I immediately switched to a new one.  In any event, I never had a brain MRI, but because I started experiencing severe anxiety I went on effexor and the headaches stopped.  This was three and a half years ago and I have been fine.  Weird.  What I think was going on was that they were migraine headaches that kicked in as a result of starting tamoxifen.  Every year when the weather turns hot I experience a similar headache for a day or two.  I also think my anxiety issues exacerbated the headaches, which is why the effexor helped.  Please do get it checked out.  I offer this story only to give you hope that it isn't mets at all.  Thats what I think you will find out.

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2010 11:44PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Wouldn't patients with the full dissection have more advanced cancers and therefore be more likely to have distant recurrences?  Am I missing something here?  OK, this is anecdotal but  . . . I had one out of three sentinel nodes positive, and therefore the full dissection, 17 nodes, although ultimately I still only had the one positive node.  Recently I went through the very wrenching process of deciding whether or not to have my ovaries removed (I finished 5 years of tamoxifen and was put into chemical menopause via zoladex).  My oncologist thought it very significant that I had a sizeable tumor that only got into one node, that this was important information about the behavior of my particular cancer and that it hadn't behaved aggressively.  As result, he wasn't pushing the oophorectomy and I chose not to have it.  What this meant to me was that the dissection wasn't just a matter of treatment but also of information gathering that was important for treatment.  We may be at the point, or fast approaching it, when this won't be necessary but i was very glad to have this information when I made this important decision.
Posts.Title: Risk after SNB/ Lillie Shockney gets it wrong kira voraciousreader

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2010 06:50AM - edited Jul 4, 2010 09:49AM by Member_of_the_Club I would add that there used to be a belief that if bc is diagnosed as metastatic from the get-go, that there is no reason to remove the primary.  Lately there has been movement in the opposite direction, with the idea that lowering the tumor load by removing the primary does have benefit for patients with mets.  Granted, distant metastasis occurs through the bloodstream, so removing nodes isn't "blocking" that but if there is a heavy tumor load in the nodes, as LindaLou says, removing the nodes decreases the work that the adjuvant therapy has to do.  I think these new studies apply to folks like me who have minimal nodal involvement.  But as I pointed out iin my earlier post, reenforced by LindaLou's post, there is an information gathering element to this as well, not just an impact on survival element.  For me this has been extremely important.  I can imagine it wouldn't be so for others. I know these new studies are important and that practices change but we should be careful about definitive statements here because there are nuances and everything is in flux.

Posts.Title: Palliative care Analemma dieMartina88

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2009 07:24PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: I think there are two different uses of the word palliative going on in this thread.  The first is palliative care focused on controlling the cancer.  This is not for comfort (well maybe kind of) but to treat the cancer.  Since it isn't intended to cure, but to control, it is called palliative. Then there is a more general kind of palliative care that is solely for comfort and not for treating the cancer itself.  I think this is what Annalemma is referring to.  It can be offered to anyone with any illness and the point is to ameliorate symptoms that cause discomfort.  The confusion here is that sometimes the word palliative is used interchangeably with hospice so we get the impression that palliative care is end of life care, but it isn't necessarily.  People in hospice do receive palliative care but you do not have to be in hospice to receive this kind of palliative care, you can also be in active treatment.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2009 10:37PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: I have a child with an autistic spectrum disorder and I have never, ever participated in or donated to an autism event.  I do feel guilty about it, but I also feel like I live it everyday and i don't need to take that on.   I actually think it is healthier for your kids not to participate in all these events.  I love the fact that they are raising money but there is a lot of romanticizing of breast cancer that goes with it and a lot of over-identifying.  I run in the Race for the Cure because I am a runner but my husband and children have never been.  I think the intense focus on breast cancer would be too much.  If I'd never had it, I might see it as a way to raise awareness for my daughter, but she's already aware. I had the same reaction to the new book about breasts for teenage girls put out by our own Dr. Weiss.  I would never give it to my daughter because she's had enough of breasts and how they can turn on you in her life.  I want her to focus on other things. I guess I'm saying you are a terrific mom.  The best gift you can give your kids is as normal a life as possible.  Difficult under the circumstances, but you deserve enormous credit for making that a priority.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2010 10:21PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: A couple of things:  First, if it is a time release capsule, it cannot be opened or crushed, even by a pharmacist.  However, you should contact the pharmaceutical companyand find out if they make it in any other form.  When my mother had brain cancer she was on an oral chemo that was time release and at one point lost the ability to swallow pills.  Turns out the pharmaceutical company made it in a powder form (which the onc didn't know) and an IV form (which he did know).  Second, there are tricks to help you get it down.  When my kids were learning to swallow pills we ordered a cup off the internet that had a special lip for the pill so when you drank out of the cup, the pill just went right down with the water.    But I understand your reluctance for this sort of thing if you tried before.  The best way to overcome phobias is short-term cognitive-behavioral therapies.  It works, even on very longstanding phobias.

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2009 11:42AM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Be prepared for him to have no reaction at all, at least at first.  Kids just handle things differently.  He may have an uptick of his usual anxiety symptoms and he may start acting out but still not want to talk about it.  I think you have to bring it up once and then follow his lead.  You also may want to tell him you are doing fine.  I don't mean to sugar coat things, but you can point out that you work and have a full life and feel good and that breast cancer is really a lot of different diseases and your breast cancer is not the same as her's.    We went through this last year when a Mom in my son's class died from the most aggressive case of bc I've ever heard of.  He just didn't want to talk about it, so I respected that.  I'm so sorry.  Remember to attend to your own feelings abut all this as well.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2010 08:41PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Good for you, everyminute.  My LE therapist told me her philosophy is that she doesn't tell women "no, you can't do that," if it is something that, as she put it, "completes your life."  She will tell women instead to listen to their bodies and will problem-solve for how it can be done most safely.  My feeling is that our doctors should help us do the things we most want to do, safely, rather than tell us we can't.  Obviously, if something is going to be very dangerous or destructive, thats something different.  But so many of these things are potentially dangerous, or may cause discomfort that we are willing to live with, in which case we should know the risks and how best to take care of ourselves when we proceed nonetheless.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2010 09:36PM - edited Jun 6, 2010 09:38PM by Member_of_the_Club Everyone is being gracious towards the moderators because they do us a great service and they did take our concerns seriously but I am really bothered by their post.  First, it makes it seem like there is no science on the subject of LE.  Granted, there isn't enough science, but there is some and this isn't just an issue of various experts' opinions and gut feelings.  Second, the whole quality of life thing can be a lazy way out.  Avoiding blood drawers on the affected arm after a SNB really isn't a quality of life issue, unless neither arm is available.  (I know bc.org agrees with this recommendation, but their "expert" does not).  And of course, LE is a huge quality of life issue.  So it seems like a no-brainer.  But Ms. Shockney thinks this will cause women too much anxiety (incredibly patronizing, I might add).  This is really, truly not an example of experts disagreeing, this is an example of one expert stubbornly putting her fingers in her ears and chanting "la la la I can't HEAR you . . ."

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2009 07:43AM Member_of_the_Club wrote: I went back and read the ask the expert transcript and I read it to say what I just wrote -- that the trend is to problem solve to find ways to enable women with LE to do the things they want to do.  I don't see this as the same thing as no limitations.  I think this approach acknowledges that some women won't be able to do some things but I can tell you that I am far more likely to be compliant about managing my LE because my therapists are not telling me to avoid things that are important to me.  This is not the same thing as telling women with LE they can fly without compression.  Yowza.  If there are actual studies showing that there is no difference flying with and without compression, I don't have a problem with such studies being published (though I would wonder if its because women have poorly fitting garments).  But i would never fly without my garments.

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2009 01:17PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Well she did refer to being stable and to early cancers disappearing.  I thought my response was very gentle -- I never called Linda an "evil baddie" nor did I want to "put the cuffs on" or "ban her from the boards."  I just disagree.  I love a great attitude and a belly laugh as much as anyone but I get very protective of women with cancer when they are told that such things are therapeutic.  If you are going through another terrible challenge -- the death of a loved one, or a divorce -- does anyone tell you to laugh through it?  Of course not.  But here are women facing the biggest, scariest, challenge of their lives.  I would rather tell them to scream "FUCK CANCER" than laugh, but thats me.  My mother died less than two weeks ago from brain cancer.  Similarly, Bren, she died only seven weeks after they found her tumor.  It was a monster.  I was grateful for the times when I could make her laugh during this really awful time.  But I also remember sitting with her when one of her cancer docs told her patients do better if they have a good attitude.  It seemed terribly unfair to me, she had already lost the ability to walk at that point, she couldn't read, she felt like crap.  When we left the doctor's office that day I told her, "Mom, you don't have to have a good attitude.  You can scream, whine and throw things."  She did laugh at that point and also said she was grateful for my words because that was exactly what she felt like doing.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2009 07:51PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: You will most likely need a glove with what they call finger stubs since your fingers are swollen.  This is what I have.  Having folks massage you may do mare harm than good so you probably shouldn't do that.  The kind of lymphatic massage that you will learn about is a different kind of massage.  Elevating the hand and arm are a good idea.  Another thing that helps is squeezing a fist while hold your hand up, kind of like a pumping motion.  Also try not to spend too much time out in the heat.  Binney will be along about the pump -- my understanding is that they really aren'y used anymore? You'll get used to how to control this and once you do you will feel better about the whole thing.  None of us like it, but most of us are doing just fine.  You will too.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2010 04:32AM Member_of_the_Club wrote: There are a lot of things that kill cancer cells in isolation.  The trick is to kill them in a human body, while leaving the healthy parts in tact.  This machine "may" go into clinical trials in a few years and already its being touted as "the answer"?  How will it kill cancer cells and leave healthy cells behind?  How will it get at micromets in the bloodstream?  Widespread mets?  I have more faith in targeted drug therapies.  I think the "cures" (as we know, bc is lots of different diseases) will be found in drugs that target specific characteristics of the cancer cells, and only the cancer cells, in the way that herceptin works only better.  Such drugs are already being researched and are in clinical trials.  I believe there are drugs in the pipeline that will save many, many women's lives.  Mmom2angels I know you mean well and we all want to see the magic bullet, but you've been posting this everywhere and I just don't think we're there yet.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2008 09:41PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: This is your decision, your's alone. Do what you feel you have to. I had a lumpectomy and rads -- and i am a fellow 34A with extremely pale skin, I mean really pale. I have been surprisingly happy with the results, and I had a 2.9 cm tumor so i was amazed at how well it looked in the end with my small breasts. The rad onc told me that skin tone does not affect how you will react to rads because it is a different kind of ray than sunlight. Breast size seems to have more of an effect, women who have larger breasts are more uncomfortable. She explained why this is but its been three years and I;ve forgotten. One last thing, many women now are being told to have radiation even with a mastectomy, even with no nodes. You might want to meet with a radiation oncologist now, before you make your decision, to make sure you know what your recommendation will be. He or she can also speak to your concerns about skin tone an breast size and rads.

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2009 02:18PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: No, no don't apologize.  Any of us would be worried. First of all, are the flashes very quick bursts or continuous, zig-zaggy things?  If the former, coupled with the blind spots, I would get to an ophthalmologist ASAP to rule out a detached retina (plus I notice you wear glasses.  Nearsightedness can increase risk).  If you are having the continuous zi-zaggy things that come with ocular migraines, I believe it is highly unusual to have it last this long.  Whatever "it" is, it sounds like it is getting worse.  You really, really need to call your neurologist and have him check it out.  You've already had a clean MRI so I think the odds are very, very strong that this isn't cancer, but it is something and you need to get it fixed.

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2008 07:11PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: While it is possible and folks are right that she should get it checked out, there are numerous other, more likely explanations.  The first is the chemo itself, especially cytoxin.  The other thing that can cause headaches is any kind of hormonal disruption.  If she was premenopausal when she started chemo she is likely in chemopause and that could do it.  I had migraines everyday for a while when I first went on tamoxifen.  Interestingly they stopped when I went on effexor, which raises another possibility -- anxiety.    She needs relief so she should speak with her docs but I think it is highly unlikely to be mets.

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2009 04:41PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Kathie, do you have LE?  If so, you should always wear a compression garment.  I am extremely active -- I run about five miles a day and work out with hand weights.  Before I had LE I did not wear garments.  I should say that this was my level of activity before my surgery so I was able to return to it quickly. After LE I always wear a sleeve and glove when I do any kind of exercise, including yoga.  I find that exercise plus garments actually helps me reduce my symptoms.  The lymphatic system has no pump of its own so exercise (controlled and with the garments) helps.  I no longer have the heaviness and aching in my arm that I was having before.  I do still have the sausage finger and sometimes my middle finger -- the expressive one! - swells, but for now at least thats all.  But I should say I have found religion on the subject of LE.  I am very careful about doing everything my LE therapist tells me to do to manage it because I don't want it to get worse.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 09:13AM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Check with your GP as well.  When I had my ocular migraine I flipped and thought it was for sure brain mets.  A friend of mine who is a doctor explained to me that when the zig-zagging thing expands (what she called "marching") they know that it is vascular and not tumor-related (phew) BUT, she said that when it happens for the first time in someone my age they often do a workup to make sure there isn't some kind of clotting thing going on.  She said that because I am on tamoxifen, which can cause clotting, I should mention it to my oncologist, which i did and he was not concerned.  However, since you are having these quite often, and they are new, you may want to make sure something funky didn't happen as a result of the heart surgery.
Posts.Title: Brain mets question magsandmattsmom Member_of_the_Club

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2008 04:34PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Your words "nauseous and overly full" rang a bell with me. About a year after I finished chemo I developed a disorder called gastroparesis, or slow stomach emptying. Generally the disorder is permanent but for me it lasted about a year and seemed to be a long term side effect of the chemo. I actually threw up several times a week. Fat is more difficult to digest so fatty foods are often a no no for folks with this disorder. A premature feeling of fullness is also a big red flag. This wouldn't explain the smudge on the liver but if it turns out to be b9 (fingers and toes crossed) ask for a stomach emptying test. Gastroparesis is an underdiagnosed disorder and often people walk around with it for a long time before getting the right treatment.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 01:39PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: I've all sorts of crises with my kids through the years so let me say this too shall pass.  Your son needs help but help is out there.  First of all, have you ever had him evaluated for learning issues or ADHD?  The bad grades may reflect that.  Even if he's done well in the past, work becomes more abstract at this age and there is an increase in demands, so if he has such an issue he may have been able to compensate in the past but can't anymore.  Hitting that kind of wall can easily cause both anxiety and anger.  As for anxiety, cognitive behavioral therapy can be really helpful for the kids this age -- its a short term, focused form of therapy that teaches kids how to handle anxieties on their own.  Finally, these could all be signs of depression as well, so if you can have him evaluated by a pediatric psychiatrist that would be a good idea.  This is absolutely not a sign of bad mothering, or I and most of us would have to be considered a bad mother.  Sometimes the only we learn abut brain differences or emotional issues in our kids is when they get pushed to the wall.  This is his biology speaking.  While he may be experiencing stress from your illness, if he is predisposed to this sort of thing it would have happened eventually with something else.  The point is that rather than blame yourself (you are a great mother) the best thing would be to call in professionals and solve the problem.  You can do this.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 08:22PM Member_of_the_Club wrote: Patti can you ask the school to do a formal evaluation for learning or developmental issues?  And if he has ADHD, is he on medication?  My daughter has ADHD and was doing fine in school but having horrific meltdowns when she got home.  She was working so hard to keep it together that she just couldn't when she got home.  Medication gave her the ability to focus like everyone else and completely turned things around.  Bit it sounds like you have a resource at the school to start with, so thats good.
